Award.AwardTitle: Patterning Vapor Deposited Polymers onto Porous Microfluidic Devices using Transition Metal Salts

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to develop an environmentally benign vapor-phase patterning method for modifying the interfacial surface properties of three-dimensional porous materials. Metal salt inhibitors will be used to control the location of polymer growth. The fundamental mechanism behind the inhibition process and the generality of the patterning method will be studied by investigating the kinetics associated with the inhibition process as a function of substrate temperature, the flow rate of the precursors, and the time of deposition. The chemical interaction between the precursors and the inhibiting salts will be studied by examining the effects of changing the initiator and monomer molecules involved in the polymerization process. The uniformity of the inhibition through the depth of the porous materials will be studied as a function of the pore size and the mean free path.

If successful, the results of this research will allow for the production of next-generation point-of-care paper-based diagnostic devices. The development of robust paper-based diagnostic devices is important for monitoring health-related issues in resource-limited environments such as personal homes and developing economies. This work will allow these devices to be patterned with a wide range of responsive and functional polymers that will greatly enhance their current analytical capabilities. This project will be used to mentor and train underrepresented high school and middle school students in downtown Los Angeles. The PI and the PI's students will work in collaboration with USC's MESA (Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement) program. The MESA program serves more than 1000 disadvantaged middle school and high school students in 23 schools in downtown Los Angeles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed several patterning methods to control the location of polymer deposition onto paper-based microfluidic devices. The development of paper-based diagnostic devices is important because these devices can be used to monitor biological and chemical analytes for healthcare and food applications. Our goal was to develop patterning methods that would allow for the addition of new functionality to these devices, allowing for better detection of analytes. We achieved our goals by demonstrating that we could pattern a wide range of functional polymers such as anionic, cationic, light-responsive, and barrier coatings onto paper-based devices in order to enhance their analytical capabilities.

Our polymerization method has several advantages. For example, no organic solvents are used during our polymerization process and therefore there is less organic waste. Also, our polymerization process is conformal and therefore the fibrous morphology of the paper is retained which is necessary to generate capillary-driven flow in these devices. Another major benefit of our polymerization technique is that multiple polymers can be stacked onto one another, allowing for several functionalities to be added to one device.

One of the patterning methods we developed involved using metal salt inhibitors. We systematically determined which salts were effective at uniformly inhibiting the deposition and we used several surface characterization tools to determine the mechanism of inhibition. Our fundamental understanding of the inhibition process allowed us to pattern lipophobic fluoropolymer barriers in order to develop paper-based microfluidic devices that could allow organic solvents to be used as the operating liquids. This work significantly expanded the applications of these microfluidic devices to be used for the detection of water insoluble analtyes such as pharmaceutical drugs and pesticides. Another patterning method that we developed allowed us to add several functionalities onto the paper-based microfluidic devices. We first deposited a coating that could passively separate analytes, which allowed a multi-component mixture to be separated into its anionic and cationic components. We then sequentially deposited a UV-responsive polymer to act as a responsive switch to control the path of fluid within the devices.

The patterning techniques that we developed allow us to extend the advanced unit operations available for paper-based microfluidics and allow for more complex diagnostics.  Although we focused on modifying the surface properties of paper, we can apply our patterning techniques to modify the surface chemistries of other three-dimensional porous materials including membranes, filters, and fabrics for applications in separations, sensing, and clothing. These paper-based microfluidic devices were demonstrated to students who visited the lab as part of USC’s outreach programs. Several undergraduate and graduate researchers were trained during this project. Several publications and scientific presentations resulted from this project.


Last Modified: 03/28/2016
Modified by: Malancha Gupta
